29.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2022
TL:DR; Director's cut non-withstanding, Bard's Tale 4 is *still* too buggy to recommend to any but the most dedicated players who enjoy nostalgia of old school games. Puzzles are a main feature of the game to break the tedium of combat.


-----------

You know, I purposely play games many years after the initial release so that I don't have to deal with the buggy messes at launch. This level of bugginess in *the director's cut* is inexcusable. If I'm not getting stuck on the environment while walking around or the game crashing and losing my progress, doors which I had unlocked are inexplicably locked again after returning to the game. After a bug filled run through the game I had to quit when one of the doors locked with a key was found closed, preventing progress. As of such it is difficult to recommend this game that is in such a state. Need I say more?

If you can somehow get the game to be stable (who knows, maybe someone loves it enough to patch it out), the gameplay itself is... okay, actually. Interspersing combat with other activities is a good design choice to mix it up, and puzzles fits the role quite nicely. For combat, I really wish the game would allow me to see the *formation* of the enemy group before I charge in so I can position my heroes better. Would save me a reload... oh wait, playing the game as intended you can't save and reload at any point. Ugh. So instead I trudge back to a save point, or rather trudge back to combat from a save point after I lost the battle. It's a time waster, essentially. Please stop wasting my time, developers.
 
mrbunnyban
0
18 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3
Non recommandé
68.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 aout 2020
Bard’s Tale IV es un juego que en si cumple, pero visto la gran cantidad de juegos de los que disponemos no merece la pena su compra.

Historia típica y nada destacable, eres el único que puedes que salvar al mundo porque sí y todos te vamos a seguir...

Combate: Es por turnos y empieza el primero que ataque. Esto deja de tener mucho valor cuando consigues a un pícaro en tu grupo (Mas o menos en 1 hora.. si no es tu pj inicial) pudiendo ir oculto para acercarte lo suficiente y empezar siempre el combate. Dispones de ciertos puntos de acción que a medida que avanzas en la trama van subiendo.

Prácticamente empezamos ♥♥♥ un grupo de 4 y ampliable hasta 6, ya sea por avance en la historia o comprando mediante tokens que obtienes en el juego dicha ampliación. Además, ♥♥♥ dichos tokens podemos reconfigurar los talentos o comprar mercenarios.

Solo disponemos de 4 ranuras para nuestras habilidades, pudiéndolas cambiar fuera del combate para “adaptarse” al enemigo, pero en mi caso apenas me ha hecho falta, tan solo tienes que detectar las mejores habilidades puesto que el resto apenas tienen eficacia.

Decisiones : Solo 2, la primera puede complicarte un poco la vida si decides mal, pero es fácilmente paliable usando los recursos del juego , la 2ª es al final del juego para completar la historia.

Dificultad: Tengo la sensación de que este juego no lo han testeado pasado el tutorial.. lo he jugado en máxima dificultad (Legendaria) y prácticamente todo el juego ha sido un paseo, incluido el enemigo final, que ni siquiera me ha podido atacar…

La dificultad va ligada a :

1º Tu equipo, que es el que te da grandes aumentos en las estadísticas y aunque a precios caros para tu nivel, tienes la opción de pillar muy buen equipo desde el principio para al menos un personaje vendiendo la gran y absurda cantidad de materiales de las que dispones (He acabado el juego ♥♥♥ cerca de 200 huesos...)

2º La configuración de tu equipo .♥♥♥ un guerrero avanzarás lentamente, si llevas 2 la mayoría de los combates pasaran a ser triviales (Tan solo por la habilidad de reducir armadura)

3º Como y cuando usar tus habilidades, además de compaginarlas entre si. ♥♥♥ esto, que no es nada difícil de dominar, puedes ganar combates “imposibles” sin ni siquiera sudar.

Suelen abusar de poner enemigos a los que NO puedes vencer para guiarte por el camino correcto. Además, en muchas zonas, te ponen a un primer enemigo bastante duro para que una vez que los eliminas.. el resto son combates triviales que no proporcionan ningún reto. (A esos enemigos no los puedes evitar yendo oculto puesto que están justamente en zonas por las que tienes que pasar).

Puzles : Al principio molan, cuando tienes que repetir el mismo tipo de puzle 5 veces seguidas ya no, y es una mecánica que repiten constantemente hasta la saciedad. Repetir y repetir el mismo tipo de puzle para poder avanzar. Un poco mas de variedad o haber eliminado esas repeticiones hubiese sido mejor.

Exploración: Mapas cerrados, ♥♥♥ bastantes secretos, pero 0 recompensa. La gran mayoría de los cofres (por no decir todos) no tienen nada por lo que haya merecido estar 10 minutos resolviendo un puzle. La única recompensa parece ser que es ser capaz de resolverlo, y es solo cuestión de tiempo.

¡¡¡Felicidades por resolver este puzle, tu recompensa son 4 coles y 3 zanahorias!!!

Economía: Durante el primer tercio del juego el dinero será un problema constante, a partir de cierto punto te saldrá por las orejas y si tienes a un pícaro ♥♥♥ la habilidad de robar entonces olvídate de pasar penurias.

Duración : Unas 70 horas si eres completista, a falta del dlc que ya completaré en otro momento. Por todo lo que he comentado anteriormente, a mi se me ha hecho un poco pesado y largo

Bugs: Algunos menores que se solucionan cargando partida, otros molestos en los que a veces el juego no reconoce al enemigo que tiene delante y no te deja atacarle ♥♥♥ un personaje.

Por último.. CTDS aleatorios. Solo he dejado una misión sin hacer y es por culpa de esto… 99 rondas seguidas contra enemigos de bajo nivel (para cuando consigues la llave). Me ha echado del juego en las rondas 89 y 83, he pasado de volver a repetirlo, total.. dudo que la recompensa merezca la pena a esas alturas del juego.

Nota final 4/10. En el mercado tenemos muchas otras opciones que lo superan ampliamente en todas en todas las facetas.
 
Thronak
5
18 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Évaluation publiée le 16 septembre 2019
Да, игра с тяжелой судьбой, сырая версия на старте, год ожидания доведения до ума, но довели же. Графен по прежнему простоват, а системные завышены, но глазу приятен, видно что создатели старались. Баги еще есть, но большая часть вычищена, и нормальная локализация завезена. И игру можно любить за увлекательную боевку, прекрасную музыку, бардова история же, и какую то теплую ламповость. Non recommandé
25.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 janvier 2020
The thing that really put me off Diablo 3 was the 'weapons are not really used' idea.
Unfortunately InXile have adapted the same philosophy in Bards Tale 4.

What it means is that it does not matter if you equip a two-hand sword or a toothpick. It does the same damage because you attack with abilities. Your characters can specialize in sword weapons but still make a sword attack with a mace equipped. Likewise you can shoot arrows even though you don’t have a bow. In fact you can walk butt naked into a fight and somehow still make an axe attack.
This is just stupid and you quickly loose any interest in your weapons because only their stat bonuses have any meaning. The game could have been implemented with just one base weapon (a small stick maybe?) with gem slots for stats or similar. Would have worked the same.

Combat also feels very limited. Its not only a matter of movement space but it seems that your options in a fight are extremely limited. When you get beat in a fight you’re left with a feeling of ‘what could I possible have done differently?’ The answer is often ‘nothing’.
My first game start was with a rogue and I was stopped at an early encounter (Green lady house). There was absolutely no way to win the fight and also no way back so I had to abandon and start a new game.
I never had that happen before in any game like this.

On the positive side graphics are nice, story is fine with some funny elements but the gameplay implementation is just terrible (and buggy).
 
thelord
0
10 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
130.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2020
Great fun! If you liked Legend of Grimrock 2 I would say this is a must buy, it's a puzzle-heavy RPG but the movement is smooth, (grid-based movement can be enabled for those who prefer that), and the combat is turn-based and somewhat tactical, and is very entertaining once you get the hang of it and have acquired more types of attacks, spells, and songs. Some combats are puzzle-like and may require to to re-equip or swap abilities beforehand-this can turn an impossible fight into a much easier one at times, as the game itself reminds you. It has a fair amount of flavor of the original Bard's Tale series in terms of lore, street names, the prominence of the bard class, boss enemies, some locations, and interstitial scenes. Strong Celtic feeling throughout.

AMAZING music, but overly repetitive if you linger in an area. Game is fairly linear, gated by mobs that may be too tough for your party, and there is an indication of mob difficulty ahead of time - if you don't get surprised.

The skill tree really shines in the later game.
There are 4 difficulty settings to suit your playstyle. I played on the "Tavern Song" difficulty, which is probably equivalent to "normal" in other games, and still found some of the combats difficult.

There are points where there isn't enough guidance to move you forward (I'm thinking of the forest). While there is fast travel, there are a number of places where significant backtracking is necessary (again, the forest is the worst offender), Graphics are pretty, and the game gives you a beautiful world to explore. I loved the level design overall.

This RPG does that have that IT factor, for me at least, that makes you want to keep playing, you do feel your party getting a ton stronger due to combinations and item drops, and tactical decisions and party build matter hugely, and you can re-spec pretty often. Story is fine. I hesitated on purchasing this for many months due to reviews but ended up loving it, flaws and all.

The game is pretty stable, but I did experience 4 CTDs, all of them in combat; occasionally the game needs a bit to catch up with all of the effects that trigger other effects and so on and can crash.
AI is OK and does tend to pick on your more vulnerable characters first.
After speaking with a few NPCs, I would be involuntarily moved backwards for several seconds. I thought something was wrong with my keyboard but I am pretty sure it's the game. Once, that caused me to encounter a mob I was not prepared for, so you might make sure you're all healed up before talking to an NPC just in case.
These issues did not hamper my enjoyment of the game much, but if I had played with "save anywhere" disabled they might have.

There are secrets literally everywhere, often hidden in plain sight, this is a game that rewards (nay, requires) obsessively peeking into every nook and cranny if you like that sort of thing. Every time you wonder "Is there any way to get up there? Is there anything behind this?" The answer is "yes" 99% of the time even if it is not obvious how to do it at first. Sometimes it requires waiting until much later in the game, other times you just really have to pay attention.

There are a few quests you may get early on that cannot be completed until much, much later in the game, and it is not clear that you should not waste time thinking about them yet. I found this a bit annoying.

There are several main types of puzzles and all of them get re-used at various points. I did tire of most of the types before the end. For me the ideal would probably be half the puzzles and at least double the number of types. Some of them felt pretty enjoyable, but some are just filler. There is an option that can be enabled to skip puzzles. I think the game would be much less fun without them.

Gold isn't that useful for anything other than crafting materials after the very early game, but this is completely true to the original Bard's Tale series (the early ones had no crafting but gold only helped you level up, heal, and regain magic points, and even that became trivial quickly). I think I prefer the Grimrock way of handling things for a game like this: no vendors and no random loot drops, everything hand-placed. In most cases in this game when you solve a puzzle you'll just get a random leveled loot drop and those tend to be better than most of the unique weapons you find, though a few of the uniques really do stand out (and are probably necessary to beat some enemies). Most of the uniques don't feel very special (several share the same abilities) and I feel there are too many of them.

For me, every RPG is a balance between fun and tedium. This game is SO close to being a classic, but errs a bit too much on the tedium side in the middle to late game. To be fair, some areas are optional or skippable to help with this, and I still had a blast and wanted to do all the content anyway. It is much better than the great majority of RPGs I have played and will be a memorable title for me. I would much rather see more quality puzzle-RPGs like this than yet another huge but hollow Bethesda experience. I imagine we won't see a Bard's Tale V, and if so that is really too bad. If I nitpicked too much above, it is because the game does so many things right, that the problems stand out all the more.
 
BravoZulu
0
12 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
64.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 décembre 2019
Mein Spielfazit vorab:
Das Spiel hat mir insgesamt viel Spaß bereitet, ist aber in seiner Puzzledichte und seinem Kampfsystem speziell und wird nicht jedem gefallen. Bugs gibt es kaum noch - ich hatte in rund 50 Stunden Spielzeit einen offensichtlichen Bug (unendlicher Fall durch den Boden). Subjektiv vergebe ich 4/5 Punkte und würde das Spiele jedem Oldschool-RPG-Spieler empfehlen, der auch mal gern ein bisschen knobelt. Wenn man keine Rätsel mag sollte man die Finger von dem Spiel lassen. Es gibt sehr viele Rätsel, die sich teilweise in der Art wiederholen (aber mit ansteigendem Schwierigkeitsgrad), und nur manche von ihnen kann man auslassen. Viele müssen gelöst werden, damit das Spiel weitergeht.

Im Einzelnen:
Story:
Die Story ist offensichtlich, der Bösewicht ist offensichtlich, kurzum - das Spiel spielt man nicht wegen der Story. Sie zieht durch die Handlung, das war es.

Gameplay:
Im Grunde wechseln sich die Elemente Exploration, Kampf und Rätsel immer ab. Zwischendurch rüstet ihr Eure bis zu sechs Helden aus oder skillt sie weiter. Durch den Directors Cut könnt Ihr umskillen, wenn ihr wollt. Zudem könnt ihr jetzt beliebig zwischendurch speichern, was den Schwierigkeitsgrad und den Nervfaktor erheblich reduziert. Die Skillungen können sich teilweise trotz gleicher Charakterklasse unterscheiden, was den Wiederspielwert erhöht. Zudem habt ihr verschiedene Möglichkeiten, Eure Gruppe aus den verschiedenen Charakterklassen zusammenzustellen.
Manko aus meiner Sicht: Es gibt wenig gute legendäre Waffen - die meisten Standard-Endgamewaffen sind besser als viele legendäre Gegenstände. Legendäre Rüstungsteile gibt es nur sehr wenige.
Weiteres Manko: Eure Gruppe kann nicht springen. In einer Waldsequenz in der Mitte des Spiels liegt ein Weg, den ihr gehen wollte, direkt unter Euch, gefühlt 30 Zentimeter tiefer, aber ihr könnt nicht dort hin, sondern müsst den ganzen Weg bis zur Kreuzung zurückgehen.

Grafik:
Die Grafik ist nicht auf der Höhe der Zeit, aber ok. Die unterschiedlichen Biome sind teilweise schön anzusehen, besonders die Eiswelt hat mir gut gefallen. Zudem gibt es sehr viele verschieden gestaltete Schauplätze, sowohl oberhalb wie auch unterhalb der Erde. Die Unterschiedlichkeit hat mir gut gefallen.

Sound:
Yes. Sehr sehr gut gelungen.

Kampfsystem:
Das Kampfsystem funktioniert ist aber ungewöhnlich und teilweise unlogisch. So könnte ihr jeden Skill mit jeder Waffe nutzen - Skill und Waffe sind also in der Spiellogik getrennt. Das führt dazu, dass ihr mit einem Messer in der Hand Pfeile schießen könnte oder mit einem Bogen in der Hand jemand erdolchen. Geht alles. Macht aber keinen Sinn. Zudem könnt ihr pro Charakter nur 4 Skills aus Eurer späten großen Auswahl im Kampf verwenden und ihr habt für Eure Gruppe nur eine bestimmte Maximalzahl an Handlungen zur Verfügung. Das führt dazu, dass ihr fast immer nur mit den Damage-Dealern angreift, während die davor stehenden Tanks einfach mal die ganze Zeit nichts machen, sondern nur durch passiven "Im-Weg-Rumstehen" den Damage-Dealer vor dem gegnerischen Hieb und einem schnellen Tod schützen. Ihr habt schnell eine gut funktionierende Taktik raus und die könnt ihr dann fast für jeden Gegner mit leichten Variationen nutzen. Zudem ist Stärke der einzige Stat, dessen Erhöhung Sinn macht. Initelligenz ist selbst für einen Magier (Practicioner) fast nutzlos. Das ist nicht besonders intuitiv. Wirkliches Rollenspiel wird insoweit bestraft weil ineffizient.

Gegner:
Die Gegner sind vielfältig und haben viele Unterschiede im Kampfverhalten. Wenn man das System aber mal verstanden hat kann man fast immer mit einer ähnlichen Taktik schnell gewinnen (s.o.).
 
Urmel
150 produits enregistrés

Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2020
First part of the game was fun. Classic RPG actions. Wondering around fighting monsters and solving quests. I liked it. Then I got to the mage tower and that game I was playing was gone. Now it's just wondering around solving arbitrary and random puzzles. Not even the fun well designed puzzles either. Just randomly thrown out there just to have puzzles it seemed. I was going to push through hoping it got back to the earlier style after this, but according to the game guide I looked at, this is it. This boring thrown together puzzles with a battle thrown in once in a while to break up the boredom is the entire game.

I feel cheated. I've played too long to get a refund and then spent 12 hours downloading this monstrosity. There are other, better classic style RPGs. Some of them even have puzzles that are fun. Play those instead.

Évaluation publiée le 5 avril 2020
Definitely recommended for fans of dungeon crawlers. It varies from awe-inspiring to frustrating but there is enough content and enjoyment to make it worthwhile.

+Visuals and environments are well done
+Excellent soundtrack and song variety
+Fully voice dialogue and party banter
+Combat is fun and a decent challenge
+Great variety of skills and items to use, craft, and upgrade
+Good custom options for characters, difficulty, saving, and old-school if desired
+Bards are actually useful

-Mediocre story
-Some obscure puzzles interfere with pacing
-Loot is often not rewarding for monsters or major puzzles
-Very infrequent fast travel, lots of backtracking

159.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 décembre 2021
Bard's Tale IV is a love letter to the original trilogy. So many call-backs that took me back 35 years to when I was slogging through the original Skara Brae. It even includes one of my all-time favorite battles with 396 berserkers. You can build your own party, but the companions who join you along the way have some really witty interactions that are fun to listen to. Not sure why dwarves don't look like dwarves, but whatever. You can opt for skipping puzzles which is great for replay. This game is a must have for old guys like me who spent hundreds of hours and used up reams of graph paper drawing maps of every dungeon back in 1985. Enjoy!
 
scott

Recommandé
380.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 septembre 2019
Having played through the original, and now several hundreds of hours into the DC, I can say that BT4 is a pretty good game. Is it perfect? No, but for an indie game, they've done really well. Some have complained about "bugs", like a graphical glitch when the DC just came out where you didn't see shadows of characters - and act as if that makes the game worthless. But nothing is further from the truth. This bug was rectified less than a week later - but alas; the negative reviews don't get adapted, of course. While the game isn't totally bug-free - what game is? - the DC has really improved a lot. It also contains a filter of the inventory now, a new song that let's you skip puzzles if you really don't feel like doing it (or can't), master-crafted weapons, and a whole new high-level dungeon (Haernhold).

When gauging if an RPG is any good, and one already goes mental by a graphical bug and thus find it "unplayable", one has to wonder whether you were fit to play RPG's in the first place. Old-school RPG players know this, and know what is important, and don't fall for that shallow mindset. You have, alas, some reviews that *do* reflect this rather biased and unwarranted negative stance.

So for people doubting or new to the game: I thought it a very interesting and compelling game. The only thing one needs to thoroughly enjoy it - aside from a keen drift for exploration and a waft of RPG-love - is to realize it's an indie game and not an AAA game of some big-shot studio, so manage your expectations (it's NOT a Witcher 3). But if you don't sweat the small stuff, love a modern take on an old-school RPG with puzzle-elements in it, and want to have a go at a pretty novel grid-based combat-system, you're bound to have fun.

I found the combat engaging and intricate, the small-talk of the characters endearing and funny, the atmospheric vibe amazing and fairytale-ish, and the Gaelic music absolutely wonderful and captivating. The puzzles were about at the right level for me: not too difficult, but not too easy neither (though they get progressively harder). But if you're less puzzle-inclined, it's not a problem, because, as said, the DC has a song that let's you bypass most puzzles if you're not fond of that, and it has an extra, large(ly) combat-oriented dungeon as well.

I thought it was a great mix, with a good vibe, and while one can always find some improvements, all in all, it's one of the better indie RPG's I played in years.

I would certainly recommend it, especially if one can buy it at a discount (the game is a few years old by now, after all). If you like a modern take on the old-school RPG genre, want to try out a pretty original grid-style combat, like puzzles and exploration, and you don't sweat the small stuff, you're certainly going to have fun with this game.

pro's:

- good to excellent voice acting on almost all NPCs/characters you can interact with
- pretty good and engaging story, with several references to the old BT stories (but perfectly playable without having done the old BT's)
- superbly and original (Celtic/Gaelic) worldbuilding and exploration
- novel gameplay and mechanics (as a modern take on old-school principles)
- myriads of items, skills, stats, and party-combinations to choose from
- engaging and sometimes funny interaction with the world and NPC's
- interesting, novel puzzles, of just the right complexity to actually make you think without becoming frustratingly difficult (DC has a song to bypass it if you're less puzzle-prone, though)
- excellent atmospheric vibe, with captivating music, sounds and songs


negs:

- (human) NPC's seem last gen and a bit outdated, graphically
- Fighting mechanics needs some time to adjust to (not FPS like)
- some small bugs are still around, and some UI and other improvements could be made
 
svdp
394 produits enregistrés
6

Recommandé
75.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 avril 2020
Что ж, наиграв 75 часов в четвёртый Рассказ Барда, не капли не пожалел об этом. Сразу же, для графоманов: да, в наши дни такой графикой никого не удивишь, хотя надо признать, она вполне ещё ничего. А некоторые пейзажи заставляют на пару секунд остановиться и полюбоваться ими. Сама же игра берет за душу совсем другим. Это полноценная RPG, ещё и опционально с классическим вариантом прохождения, аля 80-х. Что делает ее, несомненно, ещё более сложной. Боёвка в ней тактическая, необычная для многих, я бы даже сказал непривычная, что действительно делает её ещё более интересной. Сами бои всегда проходят на поле 4 на 4 ячейки. Но при этом они очень разнообразны в силу построения, как противников, так и героев, их количества, разнообразия супостатов и их умений, подкреплений, а также того кто начал бой.

Несомненным плюсом является юмор присущий серии этих игр, который вы встретите как в диалогах персонажей, локациях, так и в самом бою. Чего только стоят эти смешные и вредные милахи гоблины.) Игра не перегружена текстом и тоннами водянистых диалогов, что не делает погружение в неё менее интересным.

Теперь к самому главному, вишенке на этом торте. А это, друзья мои – головоломки! Они тут во всём. От самых простых «нажми тут – откроется там» до «вся эта карта череда головоломок и ловушек». Их тут действительно вагон и маленькая тележка. Они очень разнообразны и комбинированы. Некоторые не дадут вам уснуть, а иные бросят вызов логике и заставят ломать голову. И это большой, жирный + этой игры. Они есть и в оружие, где чтобы получить его бонусы нужно их разгадать. Причём некоторые могут быть связанны с элементами той или иной локации, записками, другие же с алтарями. Кстати это одна из причин, почему на локациях нужно быть внимательным и вертеть головой на 360, заглядывать за каждый угол, изучать каждый подозрительно торчащий кирпич. Там можно встретить символы, подсказки, тайники, кнопки и рычаги, и многое другое. Что-то будет применимо в данную минуту, а чему-то вы найдёте применение по ходу прохождения игры.

И каждая пройденная головоломка, полоса препятствий, ловушка заставит вас улыбнуться и ринуться в путь дальше, за новой порцией приключений, за новым вызовом в этой замечательной игре.
 
Феникс

14 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

0
Recommandé
74.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 octobre 2019
The Bards Tale 4: Director's Cut certainly has flaws, but is - despite these - one of the most enjoyable RPG's I've played this year. Why? Well let's take a look. This review is based on a full play-through on 'normal' difficulty, in which I visited most of the areas the game had to offer. For those that do not like to read a lot of text, here's a traditional TLDR;

Pros:
  • Exploration is fun and rewarding due to intricate level design;
  • Battles are kept fresh because you can switch tactics and party-builds;
  • Enviroments are well rendered, evocative and diverse;
  • Soundscapes and Gaelic music are beautiful and add to the immersion;
  • Puzzles can be skipped when one is stuck or doesn't like them;
  • Shrines, Offering Stones and statues add challenges, but aren't mandatory.

♥♥♥♥:
  • Storyline is bland and unimaginitive;
  • Inventory management is a chore and unintuitïve;
  • NPC's graphics look outdated and don't match the enviroments;
  • Optional grid-based movement doesn't work.

Grey:
  • Puzzles add a challenge to the game and prolong it's length, but are not for everyone.

So, on to a more in-depth review:
The Bard’s Tale IV: Barrows Deep was originally funded in a 2015 Kickstarter campaign and released in 2018. Upon it's release, it was divisive: long-time fans found a game that contained 'meta-elements' of the earlier trilogy, but also a game that was (and is) quite different from the original material. A year after the initial game, the current ‘Directors Cut’ has been released. This version offers bugfixes, ‘Quality of Life’-improvements, better performance and new content. We can thus approach the game in several ways: as a comparison to the original trilogy, a comparsion to the 2018 release (and the promises made in the Kickstarter-campaign) or, as a new game onto itself. I’ll try to touch on all of these.

World and narrative
BT4 is set in a generic high-fantasy world with a strong Gaelic influence that was not present in the original games. I think this gives the game a focus: a shared culture, communicated to the player by songs, storytelling and architecture. Despite this and despite the fact that the game has predecessors, it came as a surprise to me that world-building is quite minimal and the story felt bland and unimaginative. Sure, there are a lot of references to the earlier games and their lore, but the story of BT4 is essentially about vanquising evil foes with base motivations. And while there are things like a religious order, different regions and multiple races, none of these are fleshed out through narratives, books or songs. A game like Tyranny does this right. It immerses a player into a world and gives its inhabitants motivations for their actions. I think more could have been done on this front. For instance:

At one point you need to defeat Mangar, the foe you slew in the first BT. Just before the battle ensues, he says something along the lines of: “I’ll be made flesh once more and be able to live as a man again”. How intriguing it would have been to know more about this aspect of him, this desire. Instead, the game focuses solely on the desire for power and domination, and briefly at that. Very two-dimensional.

Gameplay, graphics and music
Despite the above, there *has* to be something special about a game that makes a player invest 70+ hours into it, right? Indeed. One of the things BT4 nails down is exploration. Sure, the game’s story is linear, but wow.. There’s a lot of stuff to do here. Every part of the world offers nooks, crannies and secrets to discover. There are shrines to activate, offering-stones to figure out and weapons to unlock. A lot of players, both the ‘graph-paper’-loving old-skool ones and those waned on quest-markers, will find this part rewarding.

And then there are the battles. These play out different than the ones of the original games, but are satisfing in their own way. I’ve seen players compare them to chess and I think that’s an apt observation. Your party has several ‘action’-points and you choose what character uses which skills in each turn. And, rather than allowing stats to damage foes within a certain ‘damage-range’, items and skills affect each other in precise ways. Throughout the game, you level up and learn new things. As you visit new areas, enemies grow in power and use different strategies, thereby challenging you to adapt. Clearing a battlefield was never boring for me and the adaptive music helped to keep the feeling of flow going.

Speaking of music… a lot has been written about this, so I’ll be brief: this game has some of the best music and soundscapes I’ve yet encountered. Upon starting the game once, my kids gathered round me to listen to ‘Snow in Summer’ and I often found myself stopping to admire little bits of song in villages and the streets of Skara Brae or just listen to the frogs near Inshriach Forest.

Graphics are evocative as well, at least as far as the enviroments are concerned. Dungeons, forests, towns.. They look great and add to the atmosphere of the game. The same cannot be said about the NPC’s, however. When you look at older games such as Bioware’s Dragon Age: Origins and Mass Effect, you see that - despite their age - their characters look more convicing. Sure, these games *were* about character interaction, while this game is not, but still. A low point for me were:
the Selkie Sisters in the Isle of Stronsea. Uhrg.

So.. Some good points and some bad points. Is there anything else you need to know before deciding to buy this? Well yes…

The problem with puzzles
While it was made clear in the Kickstarter-campaign that BT4 would contain puzzles, a lot of players were surprised that problem-solving became one of the main pillars of the game’s design. I think the game is better for it, but its good that the DC adds an option (in the form of a non-intrusive song) to skip them. Puzzles, at least 'set-piece' ones like in this game are something you see more in an adventure game: they are thought up by the developers and rely on deductive reasoning: e.g. you think logically about the problem they present and try to solve them by experimentation.

RPG's have traditionally relied on inductive reasoning: rules govern a world and a player learns these and notices patterns. (for instance: equipping a +2 sword you found will probably do more damage than your basic one). The simulation of a world through rules and statistics form the core of most RPG’s and inductive reasoning has been *the* fundamental philosophy ever since the D&D rules first appeared. For RPG-players, the heavy focus on puzzles here can feel annoying and even outlandish. You can skip them, but at the same time you might feel you might be missing something essential about what the devs intended for you to experience.

Another puzzle for me (lame, I know) was the way inventory-management was designed. This DC has a filter, so you can sort through stuff like weapons, armor and edibles etc., but it could be more intuïtive, especially when buying or selling stuff in a shop. It’s not a big deal and this might very well be one of the areas that will be patched, so… Onward to my…

Final Thought
I loved this game. Despite the flaws I’ve written about, it kept me going and I kept enjoying myself. The exploration and battles are exemplary and - for me - the puzzles are a breath of fresh air. I think InXile is one of the best game developers active this day, releasing quality titles with differing designs that are fun to play. This game is no exception.
 
Zwarteziel
940 produits enregistrés

I managed to take my non ideal team (ideal = 3 dwarves front, 3 outlanders back) all the way to the 2nd mangar fight, if you aren't running ideal, good luck. There is no fun to be had in a game that forces specific builds and such nonsense. Why bother with character creation and such if your game is designed to force everyone to use the same cookie cutter nonsense.

The game is simply designed to give people headaches and it works great in this regard.

Also the Mostly positive rating is BS, as they removed their older version of the game from the store to ditch is negative reviews.

Non recommandé
48.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 octobre 2019
I pledged the original Kickstarter but, due to an old PC at the time the game was out, I was only able to play now, with the DC version.
The game has a beautiful atmosphere. I LOVED walking on Skra Brae and the other starting areas with the gaelic songs. They are simply beautiful and I found myself listening to them even when not playing the game. The acting is well done and it put me in full nostalgia time when touching some of the original characters from the I, II, III games (I grow up with them, dammit!).
Unfortunately, even if the locations are always beautiful and very different one from another, and all charming, the game itself, the one you play and should enjoy, is not very good.
The RPG part is sick, the action point and combos at first are funny but become quickly less enjoyable. The itemization is poor and items starts to look all the same but with higher stats. The elven weapons are a cool concept but let's say they're not very well done. The PC skills are nice but some of them are not very clear on how they work and other repeats on different classes.
The PUZZLES are a no-no. When I first jumped into them I was like "ohhh, this is a welcome change of pace!!!" but when I started realizing that 70% of the game ARE PUZZLES I quickly become annoyed. Also the new ability that lets you auto-solve them sometimes bug the game.
The BUGS are very well done. I mean, with all this time, they are a game feature, aren't they? I will not list them, a lot of other reviews cover them, but there are a LOT of bugs.
So, all in all, I had a great time for 10-15 hours. After that it's mostly the puzzles that stopped me from coming back. At 35 hours, more or less, I'm in the final part of the game but I don't know if I wil find the strenght to jump back and deal with all the blood puzzles that keeps coming room after room (they also look all the same, graphic speaking).
Let's say that if they took the look and feel of the game and filled it with the classic Bard's Tale engine this would have been The Bard's Tale 4, and I would be still playing it, with 100hrs under my belt. Too bad it isn't.
 
RedPanda

Recommandé
60.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2020
Предупреждение: в игре количество головоломок на единицу площади данжа превышает только количество литров выпитого бардом алкоголя на этой же площади!
В город со смешным названием Скара Брей опять пришла беда: местные религиозные деятели плавно вводят в обиход кровавые репрессии, мутные типы в мантиях поклоняются забытым богам и пророчат неведомое, нежить восстает из могил, а бандиты и гоблины (размножаются почкованием) заполонили фэнтези-отчизну просто в чудовищных пропорциях. Власти, как вы догадываетесь, бездействуют. А это означает лишь одно: пришло времечко искателям приключений объединиться, чтобы сорвать покровы тайн, срубить головы злодеям и выпить море пива. Настало время меча, магии и хмеля!
Игра представляет из себя партийная dungeon crawler на шесть персонажей, с пошаговыми тактическими боями, которые на высоком уровне сложности просто взрывают мозг. Ограниченные возможности по восстановлению здоровья во время сражения поначалу могут вводить в ступор, и единственный выживший в партии по окончанию баталии – это весьма вероятный сценарий (и сценарий позитивный) каждой второй битвы по крайней мере в начале игры. Благодаря умениям вора можно (и нужно) проскальзывать мимо слишком сильных отрядов врагов. Ресурсы для крафта ограничены, товар у торговцев ограничен, возможности для сброса навыков и найма новых персонажей также ограничен. Классическая суровость жанра налицо, но стоит только разобраться в механике, сколотить свою партию, где в авангарде будут три воина-гнома, получить класс целителя в партию, найти пару-тройку артефактов столетней выдержки и конвейер по превращению врагов в труху будет построен.
Также несомненный плюс игры – это музыкальное сопровождение. Еще бы, ведь игра про бардов! Скандинавские фолк мотивы слышны тут повсюду – из каждого закутка города звучит свой напев у каждой таверны горланят свою песню. В каждой успешной партии должен быть свой бард и тонны алкоголя, который ему нужно скармливать как уголь паровозу.
P.S. В Director's Cut ввели новое высокоуровневое подземелье с читер-оружием, а также сбалансировали сложность - на легенде теперь реально пройти игру (гоблины-шуты больше не ваншотят).
 
R. Raven

Recommandé
146.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 novembre 2021
Love the game, one of the most underrated games on steam. But a BIG warning. Game relies too heavily on puzzles, which was my only complaint after completing. In some areas you can't advance a few minutes with puzzle after puzzle which was somewhat annoying. Having said that, the puzzles are original enough that keep the interest to continue up. I wish that the devs, if they release another game, would bring down a notch or two the number puzzles. I beat the NES version 30 years ago and have not played another version until now, so no biased fanboy opinion of the series here. What you get is a great dungeon crawler with outstanding music and ambiance sounds, charming and detailed graphics, nicely animated combat, decently acted and funny voice-overs from your characters and npcs, and fun combat. Playing on normal I had to go back respec party members in different occasions to advance in some encounters so the challenge is there, and can be adjusted in the options. There are also options to keep it old school with grid movement, maps off etc. A gem in a genre which lacks new and fresh entries, unfortunately. Definitely recommend, specially if you like a puzzle heavy dungeon crawler.

What an awesome CRPG dungeon crawler hybrid. It was gutted at its original launch because of the god awful stability and performance issues, which have been largely fixed in the Director's Cut, largely. It has that feeling of classic RPGs that do not hold your hand and where death awaits around every corner if you don't plan properly. If the puzzles annoy just read a guide and skip them, you'll still get your money's worth from gameplay alone. Special mention goes to the awesome Gaelic and new age music that permeates the game and gives it its own unique atmosphere. 8.5/10

1
Non recommandé
116.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 aout 2020
This is one of those games where I had difficulty deciding on whether to recommend it or not, given that I purchased the Director's Cut version on sale with all the extra goodies included, which represents pretty good value for money. Heck, I got the base game, the remastered versions of Bard's Tale 1 to 3, the digital soundtrack (though take note it's only volume 1 of 3 volumes - the other 2 volumes you have to buy separately) and a bunch of other digital odds and ends for the equivalent of around $7 or so! Ultimately though, I have to rate the game negatively, despite the good parts, as I found it to be more of a slog than actual fun.

What's good?
- Soundtrack and setting. Just like the previous Bard's Tale game (the one that was released in about 2004), a good portion of this game's budget seems to have been spent on the wonderful soundtrack, which consists of a selection of English and Gaelic songs. These, along with the Scots voice acting, add to the atmosphere of the historical Scottish setting of the game nicely.
- Some nice touches like enemies taunting you in combat ("I'll dink yer *rse, sunshine!")
, responding when your bard plays a tune ("what is that horrible music???"), genuinely funny skills like cavity search, etc.
- Nice strategic combat system, though it is a bit limited and gets a little repetitive after a while.

What's bad?
- Honestly one of the buggiest games I have ever played. The game for me in about 55 hours of gameplay was crashing to desktop around probably every 8 to 10 hours on average, usually in dungeons. I had to replay one boss fight because of a crash just after finishing it the first time. I would recommend you choose the option to save anywhere in the game instead of only at the totems if you start a new game because of this. I also had issues with an item in my inventory duplicating itself and my party stuck on moving forward each time an NPC initiated dialogue with me.
- Considering it is being touted as an RPG, the actual RPG aspects of the game. This might not be such an issue for other players, but I found this game to be more of an adventure/puzzle game than anything else. You have virtually no choice in dialogues other than to accept or decline quests, there is no option to talk to any of your companions while they are in your party (and not much when they are out of your party), you only have 4 classes to choose from, a very limited selection of portraits to choose from which kind of pushes you into playing as the default character (the aptly named bard, Melody) and your stats like strength etc are determined solely by your gear and the skills you choose for your character. Also, why are dwarves suddenly these human sized folks with knobby heads and grey skin??? For some strange reason, you can only have up to 4 of your skills readied for use in combat at any time. Combat is quite tough and will force you to pick the most optimal skills for your character so that your party works well as a unit, rather than selecting skills with role playing in mind. The game encourages exploration but then railroads you by blocking off lots of areas with locked/blocked doors or groups of enemies that are too tough for your party to take on. You will get quite tired of seeing the word "BLOCKED" when you click doors and gates in this game.
- The puzzles. I don't mind these in moderation, but it gets really tedious when you are constantly bombarded with them. By the time I reached the third area in the game in the forest, I was starting to get annoyed with the game. You get this one area where, in a nutshell, you have to guide this floating fairy light through an obstacle course to unlock a gate at the far end. You do this, and.....you get to another enclosed area with a slightly more complex layout and another fairy light to guide through it. Then you get through that....and....more of the same again. Now imagine having to do that about 5 or 6 times in a row.
- The lack of polish. NPCs like merchants will continually repeat the same dialogue each time you chat to them. Some of the graphics, like the characters, close up textures of some objects, and the facial animations, look like something out of a game from 10 to 15 years ago. Numerous spelling errors. Lack of in-game exposition. For example, you will often be told by NPCs to go to a specific area for a quest but are given no indication of where the area actually is, unless you turn on the quest tracking option for helpful pointers. There seems to be no way to delete your old saved game profiles. This, along with the bugs gives the impression of a game that was rushed out of the door.

This game, as I mentioned earlier, does have some nice touches, but it is simply too much of a puzzle game and not enough of an RPG for my liking. I'll be curious to see what InXile comes up with next now that they should have a far bigger budget to play around with.
 
MR67
0
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
34.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 aout 2021
Quick Sum:
You'll leave the game feeling sad at all the things that could have been. The music and environments are worth a run through, but the story and game play will leave you bored. I will recommend it cause its a classic series that I don't want to see die, with some good music and if nothing else take the time to play the 3 original games that comes with it.

Graphics: 6.5/10
The environments in the game are actually not bad, with great touches to bring things to life and overall decent textures. You feel the fantasy world come to life but a few poor character models and a reuse of some props really bring it down a notch or two. This along with the sometimes glitchy issues you ruin the immersion.

Sound/Music: 8.5/10
Wow, I wanted to give this such a higher score and it deserves it for the soundtrack. Great songs that really immerse you and make you feel like a bard. It's sad then that the placement and use of them were poorly done. While at times coming into a inn I'd fine myself stopping to listen to a character sing or stop to listen to the song in the world, there was just as much random placement of music that came out of nowhere and didn't really belong. Voice acting was ok, noone stood out as horrible, but you do get a couple cringe-worthy moments. I'll probably be listening to and putting on the soundtrack at times when i'm in a fantasy mood or on a D&D session.

Story: 3/10
Set after the original 3 bard tales games, you are a character of either you're own creation or a pre-made that gets tangled up in.. well it dosn't really matter. By the end of the game you care less for what's happening as a whole. They throw villans at you from past games, but without really any build-up and the final boss is just disappointing. You do get to care for a couple party members and you'll barely get any enjoyment out of side quests. I did enjoy the first few hours of storyline being underground and exploring the old city, but as the game went on..so did my attention span.

Gameplay: 4/10
A throwback to classic CRPG's of old. Bard's Tale uses a turn based system on a grid. In exploration mode a FPS style game play is given or you can turn on classic mode and use a grid to move, but once battles hit you get a tactical sense. Yet that all washes away after awhile as the games balancing system seems to be out of sort. One minute you'll be fighting easy creature and the next a group will come by that will stomp you in the same area with no real reason why? mixed that with some creature only kill-able with certain setups. Characters can be recruited and classes, skill points and standard rpg fare are here, but with the way the difficulty curves it almost better to exploit the system then to freely put points into things to test out.

Overall: 5/10
It's a shame as I grew up playing old CRPG's like this. I love fantasy settings and everywhere you look this game had potential that seem to just fall short of being there. The music while great was poorly executed when it got in game, the gameplay while fun at start becomes a slog , with the storyline just feeling like a "what can we cram in here to appeal to old fans". If you can get it on sale, and starving for some RPG love pick it up, but for the most part I'd just turn on the soundtrack somewhere and dream of what the game could have been.
 
Lorebook
2,116 produits enregistrés
0
13 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 mai 2020
I went into "Bards Tale IV" curiously hopeful. The game had received mediocre reviews, but indications were that, in the months since its release, various patches and updates had rectified many of the issues. Plus, while I find the whole dungeon-crawl genre extremely dated - retro gaming generally does not appeal to me - I had rather enjoyed my time with the "Bard's Tale Trilogy" remake, and I was interested to see where the developers were taking the series after a 30 year hiatus. So, despite some qualms, I decided to approach the game with an open mind and do my best to enjoy the experience.

With the latter, at least, I failed utterly.

It's not that I think "Bard's Tale IV" is a bad game; it's not. It is disappointingly mediocre, but I have played - and completed - worse titles. Its visuals are certainly impressive enough; no, not in a "Star Wars Battlefront" "oh-my-god, it looks so real!" way, but it has a pleasantly grimy medieval feel to it. It captures the mood of the game perfectly. I've no real complaints there. And it's gameplay? It's not *terrible*; I can see how the developers were trying to advance the original trilogy's step-based combat into something a bit more tactical, and I can applaud their attempts at innovation, even if I didn't enjoy it.

But, this game does NOT feel like Bard's Tale.

Oh sure, there are a lot of references to the older games - mentions of how Tarjan destroyed the city back in the third game, or revisiting Kylearan's Tower, a location from the first. Garth the blacksmith is back; so are the hooded members of the Review Board who level you up. Superficially, it has all the appearances of being a sequel. But beyond that? It might a well be an entirely different game entirely.

Its levels and maps are tiny, lacking the terrible trap-filled mazes that defined the series. The combat encounters are against a mere handful of monsters - in prior games, you'd could often face off against hundreds of foes. Your spells are so nerfed that few will take down a enemy by themselves; this in a series which once boasted the NUKE spell that could slay dozens with a single casting. The treasures and weapons lack impact. The leveling system is a mess of pointless skills. The setting lacked that wonderful melange of ideas and genres that made the earlier games so entertaining, opting instead for a rather uninspired pastiche of Ireland. It was, all in all, everything Bard's Tale was not.

Perhaps those lacking that nostalgic love for the original games would not be so bothered by these failings. Then again, those who didn't appreciate those older games probably wouldn't be attracted to this game either; certainly its gameplay isn't so exciting or innovative as to draw them in; there are so much better games available these days. So in this regard, "Bard's Tale IV" fails on both accounts, appealing to neither long-term fans nor new gamers.

It's quite possible the game isn't really that bad; I admit, I only stuck with it for a few hours. But it got to the point I was avoiding my computer entirely, because I felt obligated to keep playing "Bard's Tale IV" before I started something else (I eventually realized I had to abandon the game or give up computer games entirely). Maybe had I stuck with the game a bit longer, the gameplay would have drastically improved, the setting would have returned to what I loved about the older games. Maybe. But I doubt it.

Even though it hurts me to do so, because - in the end - "Bard's Tale IV" isn't a terrible game - I just cannot recommend it. It disappoints fans and non-fans alike; there's simply nothing here that makes it worth a purchase.
 
Spalls Hurgenson
0
16 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
32.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 novembre 2023
I really tried to like this game. I played the original Bards Tale in 1988 on my Commodore 64 and was looking forward to this new installment.

The graphics and sound is good but the gameplay have some real problems.

1. Too many puzzles! The game is filled with puzzles you have to solve to progress. In the first third of the game they are passable but in the midgame they get very numerous and annoying and I tend to frequently look for the solution online since I don´t wan´t to spend my tight gaming time solving puzzles.

2. The fights are too hard. I barely managed to play at normal until the midgame when I just had to switch to easy mode. Because I would have to use up all of my healing food and potions between each fight.

3. Very limited amounts of equipment and gear. There is a very limited range of weapons and armour to choose from regardless of how much money you have. This means that if you are stuck on hard fights but have saved money you have no way to use them to get you better armours or weapons because they dont differ much

4. Opportunity points. Regardless of if you have 3 or 6 members in your party you still only have 4 opportunity points to act in each round which means several members will have nothing to do except acting as meat shields. That makes the fights quite booring and the use of adding new characters to the party is almost useless.

Result: I quit playing after reaching the midgames. The world is very empty. The dialogues booring. There is no interactions with anything. The game started well but it got booring as soon as you left Skara Brae.

My final rating is 3 out of 5. If you get this on at 75% sale it might be worth it.
 
karolinerna2000

14 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

0
Non recommandé
16.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 février 2020
I progressed about one quarter the way through the main quest before I decided to call it quits. The bones of a good RPG are here, as combat can be fun and tactical, but the game is undone by some baffling design decisions.

The primary offense is that, while you can learn new active abilities as you level up, you can only have 4 readied at any given time, severely limiting the actions available to your characters during combat. What's worse, if you have an item that grants you an ability, that ability takes up one of your 4 precious ability slots, meaning that's one fewer of your character's abilities that is available. Shockingly poor design, seemingly deliberately designed to make the game less fun. The only justification I can see for it is to limit the number of on-screen options available so that the interface is streamlined for console users, but c'mon.

Secondarily, the Bard class specifically is poorly designed, because they are are reliant on crafted items (alcohol) to be able to use their bard-song abilities. I'm someone who doesn't particularly enjoy crafting in RPGs, and requiring this class to use these items means having a bard requires a lot more grinding to make sure you have enough booze stocked. What's more, the bard has to have a special item equipped in their trinket slot to be able to use alcohol (i.e. use their basic class abilities), further limiting their options in combat.

A lot of work obviously went into this, and there are a number of things to like, but I can't remember the last time a game with such good fundamentals and potential committed such grievous own-goals in its implementation.
 
Grimshackle
0
15 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
13.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 avril 2020
Многие из Вас еще даже не родились, когда вышла первая часть "The Bard’s Tale". В далеком 1985 году появилась одна из первых компьютерных ролевых игр от первого лица. Безусловно не первая, но возможно одна из самых известных на тот момент. С тех пор прошло много времени и индустрия видеоигр не стояла на месте. Теперь для нас в порядке вещей огромные, бесшовные миры, лутбоксы, микротранзакции, лицевая анимация, потрясающая графика и трассировка лучей.

Летом 2015 года Брайан Фарго, тот самый, который является автором и соавтором таких игр как "Wasteland", "Stonekeep", "Fallout", "Baldur's Gate", "The Bard’s Tale", "Hunted: The Demon’s Forge" и многих других - начал сбор средств с помощью Kickstarter на "The Bards Tale IV".

Жанр "dungeon crawler", который не так часто сейчас встречается, не что иное, как Ваш шанс приобщиться к классике, завернутой в новую обложку. Садясь за "The Bard’s Tale IV", нужно приготовиться к тому, что мир игры — сплошное мета-подземелье. Пещеры, леса, улочки, заснеженные острова — всё слеплено из тесных до «клаустрофобности» коридоров.

Эта игра морально устарела, многое в ней могло бы быть иначе - более современным и свежим, но изюминка этого проекта именно в ностальгических элементах. И несмотря на бережное отношение к классике, здесь есть много вещей, которые помогут Вам не бросить этот проект с первых минут. Ну и "Бардовская сказка" не была бы собой, если бы не потрясающая музыка, которая будет сопровождать Вас с самого начала Ваших приключений.

Единственное, что действительно кусается - цена. И если бы не мой щедрый друг - "Roland the Thompson Gunner", то я наверное еще нескоро пополнил свой игровой опыт этим замечательным проектом. За что ему огромное спасибо =)

Не могу рекомендовать эту игру всем, она безусловно нишевая и сделана для фанатов серии, но если Вы готовы потерпеть несовершенство данного проекта, то он откроет Вам свою поющую душу.
Умные, взрослые и необычные игры в кураторской группе The Clever Gamer
 
tomasribakov
1,465 produits enregistrés
0

537.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 avril 2020
This is a deep, engaging adventure with memorable characters, mind-bending puzzles, and captivating battles. 60+ hours to complete, many, many more if you like to ferret out secrets, which are hidden around every corner.

PROS:
+ Complex and meaningful skill trees. You will debate your progression path at every level
+ Deep and captivating combat. Varied enemies will force you to constantly develop new strategies
+ Truly jaw-dropping visuals in some areas. UE4 shines in this title.
+ AAA+ sound design. Up there with the best environmental sound and musical scores in ... well, ever, maybe. Play with headphones or good 5.1 speakers.

♥♥♥♥:
- Non-plot optional side areas can be dauntingly difficult
- Still some minor bugs and crash-to-desktop issues
- Forced homages to previous releases and kickstarter backers can be hokey/distracting

Overall, a must-buy title. The Director's Cut positions this title to become a decades-spanning cult classic.
 
Chilkoot

Évaluation publiée le 22 avril 2021
Update halfway or more through the game [over 40 hours now]: I quit. I don't normally do that after playing so much, but I got to the Mangar fight and apparently my entire group and loadout is wrong (it seems there's really very few setups you can beat him with, and no way to know this ahead of time). So I'd have to respec my whole team and/or take a bunch of people I never use, change all their gear, etc. Just to beat this one boss. (And yes my whole team is level 18, which by the way took killing every single mob I could get to.) Not worth it, waste of time.

Bought it on sale for the heck of it, haven't regretted it. Yes, the graphics aren't great but it's not like, KOTOR or EQ or anything. I do like turn-based/tactical combat so the format is fun (I never played this "back in the day" so it's kind of new to me). The writing is good, VA is good, and as someone else mentioned it's really cool that it's all gaelic/celtic based. Definitely recommend.

Recommandé
58.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 mai 2020

Dopo aver terminato questo lungo viaggio (58 ore circa), ho deciso di buttare giù due righe su questo gioco.

TBT 4 è un GDR che strizza l'occhio ai vecchi titoli della serie, dungeon crawler ♥♥♥ griglia di movimento quadrata e combattimento a turni. Quella che salta subito all'orecchio appena avviato il titolo è un'ottima colonna sonora che preannuncia l'amore e la cura messi nella realizzazione di questo gioco: basti pensare la scena del bardo che riepiloga le nostre avventure durante ogni volta che avvieremo la partita. Anche visivamente il gioco regala ottimi scorci grazie al UE 4.

Ora passiamo alle note dolenti di questo gioco.

Nonostante la cura e l'amore TBT 4 presenta diverse pecche, molte pecche; si può sorvolare sui tempi di caricamento, risolvibili grazie agli SSD, le texture che non vengono caricate e gli oggetti direttamente in bassa risoluzione, la scarsa ottimizzazione e la musica, che seppur meravigliosa, diventa ripetitiva, ma non si può sorvolare sui problemi di gameplay. Partendo dal problema più triviale,come la gestione dell'inventario, che a causa della mancanza di un pulsate per ordinare il tutto automaticamente ci si ritroverà a giocare a tetris più del voluto, fino al level design, che obbliga a fare avanti e indietro tante volte, passando per i troppi puzzle e combattimenti, che tendono a glitcharsi.

Per quanto riguarda l'inventario c'è un'opzione filtro che auto riordina l'inventario, ma non permette di spostare gli oggetti e purtroppo non elimina le sessione di tetris.

I combattimenti, per quanto tattici e anche impegnativi (all'inizio), diventano una rottura di scatole per via della bassa sfida (metà-fine gioco), anche grazie ai glitch dove le animazioni si bloccano, i personaggi diventano non selezionabili o l'ia che impiega tanto tempo per fare 2 azioni di numero.

I puzzle, per quanto interessanti e simpatici diversivi, sono veramente tanti e spezzano troppo il ritmo dell'esplorazione e passano dall'essere incredibilmente stupidi (spingi un masso di uno spazio) al "dov'è la guida?".

Il gioco presenta una buona quantità di contenuti per un totale di minimo 50 ore di gioco per fare tutto quello che c'è da fare.

Il mio consiglio è di prenderlo in sconto. 7/10

 
[LVG]Painmaker87
2,265 produits enregistrés
0

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante

Évaluation publiée le 11 mai 2020
Это какое-то издевательство - русский язык в игре ужасен. И речь идёт даже не качестве перевода (хотя переводчики явно русским в полной мере не владели, а часть перевода так вообще с гугл транслейт взята по ощущениям), а о том, что перевод неполный - не переведены названия, имена, скиллы и т.п. Куча фраз в переводе сделана или не к месту или же вообще перепутана. Играть в такое в текущем состоянии - себя не уважать.

Non recommandé
23.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 aout 2019
Déçu par le jeu de base, j'attendais cette nouvelle version avec autant d'enthousiasme que de méfiance. Entrons dans le vif du sujet en parlant technique sans plus attendre. Alors que sur mon I7 7700k+1080Ti+SSD+32Go, j'étais à la peine en 1080P sur la version classique, ici les premières heures passées à jouer en 2k n'ont souffert d'aucun ralentissement, plantage ou bug, me permettant ainsi de profiter pleinement de l'aventure. On dispose d'un affichage plus fin sur les décors, les personnages aussi même s'ils restent perfectibles, l'interface et les différentes fenêtres m'ont semblé plus lisibles et plus claires et l'inventaire permet ENFIN de disposer du tri. Le jeu n'a pas radicalement changé mais pour le moment l'expérience est agréable et s'approche de ce que j'attendais du titre à sa sortie.

Après quelques heures supplémentaires, je tiens quand même à préciser que le jeu souffre encore de choix très discutables en terme d'équilibrage (à mon goût), d'une gestion économique assez frustrante (Ex: une épée achetée 430Po, revendue à peine 60 au même marchand, un mini boss qui loot...12Po), la prise de risque lors des combats qui n'est toujours pas récompensée que ce soit par l'expérience ou le loot, et une fâcheuse tendance à te proposer des affrontements contre des ennemis nettement plus forts même en mode normal. C'est d'autant plus pénible dès lors que le jeu rajoute dans ton groupe un pnj de quête avec peu de points de vie et un équipement médiocre, le rendant ainsi vulnérable à des one-shot de la part de 'simples archers'. Le jeu manque toujours aussi cruellement d'ambiance, la faute à des pnjs peu expressifs, d'une gestion des musiques parfois très maladroite (mention spéciale à l'ivrogne sur le quai qui chante aussi bien qu'un équipage au grand complet), ainsi que d'environnements trop statiques, tous ces détails qui auraient pu faire la différence. Autant certains aspects étaient excusables sur la version d'origine, autant je suis assez déçu de les retrouver sur cette nouvelle mouture.

Je modifie une dernière fois mon évaluation après la rencontre d'un bug déjà présent à savoir le curseur de la souris qui reste 'enfermé' dans une zone beaucoup plus petite que l'écran de jeu, interdisant l'accès à tout se qui se trouve autour et obligeant à quitter et relancer le tout. Rajoutons à ça des micro freezes lors de l'accès à l'inventaire ou lors de déplacements en donjons (problème apparu après quelques heures), un système de tri encore bancal, on fait toujours défiler les pages de l'inventaire en passant maladroitement sur les flèches associées avec un objet en main. Le travail effectué est décevant et entre une aventure mal racontée, l'absence de personnages charismatiques ou attachants, des pnjs qui proposent des dialogues aussi superflus qu'inutiles, des énigmes et des casse-têtes beaucoup trop intrusifs de part leur quantité sans que cela n'apporte rien en terme de progression, le jeu flirte trop souvent avec le mauvais goût. Les combats ne sont pas à la fête non plus, Ex:..Vous frappez un ennemi disposant de 10HPs avec une frappe à 7dgts direct+3 dégâts de feu pendant 2 tours. L'ennemi à qui il ne reste que 3 points de vie devrait normalement mourir dès le début de son tour grâce au 3 points de dégâts de feu mais non, il va d'abord utiliser toutes ses aptitudes avant de rendre l'âme, je vous laisse juge. Bien évidemment je ne recommande pas le titre.
 
Neskouik
195 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
28.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2020
The Bard's Tale IV: Director's cut me ha ofrecido la experiencia de exploración de mazmorra más divertida y satisfactoria que he tenido en años. Y eso es decir mucho.

Para hablar de "The Bard's Tale IV: Director's cut" hay que entender el juego y la propuesta, he visto como algunos jugadores que no han comprendido en su conjunto la obra de la que estamos tratando, han atacado duramente el juego. La crítica más común, más allá de los aludidos bugs y crashes (que yo aún no he experimentado) viene del hecho de que el juego presenta gran cantidad de puzzles y acertijos que "lastran" el esperado ritmo de exploración-combate-exploración-combate.

The Bard's Tale busca ofrecer una verdadera experiencia de rol, un desafío al ingenio del jugador tanto como a su habilidad para gestionar y manejar a un equipo en combate, por ello se centra muchísimo más en contar una historia y en envolvernos en una aventura que en empujarnos al ancestral arte del reparto de toñas. The Bard's Tale IV tiene muy en cuenta las raíces roleras de las que bebe, esas aventuras de lápiz y papel que inspiraron los primeros RPG de mazmorreo, y sabe que gran parte del tiempo que se invierte en una aventura así es resolviendo intrincados acertijos dentro de los calabozos.

Por tanto, equilibra ♥♥♥ gran cuidado una aventura en la que por un lado tenemos un mundo grande y vivo que explorar, por otro ofrece diversos puzzles y desafíos intelectuales, por una tercera parte nos somete a la buena y antigua tradición de reventar monstruos a espadazos y por último nos viene contando una fascinante y cautivadora historia de una forma cuidada y ♥♥♥ mimo.

El conjunto de todas estas piezas, aunadas ♥♥♥ delicado cuidado por el detalle y en equilibrio es la verdadera virtud del juego, y lo que logra transmitir la sensación de aventura como muy pocos juegos modernos consiguen.

En cuanto a la primera parte, la exploración, tenemos un mapa extenso y muy completo, lleno de recovecos que explorar, pequeños secretos que descubrir en cada esquina y herramientas para interactuar ♥♥♥ él, en forma de mágicas canciones que nos permiten activar en el mundo tal o cual efecto, así como de herramientas de exploración que nos permiten acceder a tal o cual zona para descubrir tal o cual cofre que abrir. No hay sitios vacíos, cada casilla del mapa está puesta ♥♥♥ una intención, y el diseño general invita a tener siempre un ojo alerta, por si hay algún secretillo que abrir. También veremos que por el mundo hay una serie de estatuas mágicas que se resuelven ♥♥♥ un código. Las pobres estatuas son fuente de frustración para algunos, según he visto. La clave para descifrar el código viene en un disco digital que trae el juego ♥♥♥ los extras y que colocando adecuadamente siguiendo las indicaciones de la estatua y el almanaque del gremio de aventureros nos permite descubrir que ofrenda hacer para recibir tal o cual objeto. Estas estatuas son un divertido guiño a los sistemas anti-pirateo de los juegos clásicos del género, y, por supuesto, totalmente opcionales. Descifrar la clave no supone ningún reto para el jugador inteligente, y quien no sepa seguir las indicaciones, puede ignorarlas sin ver lastrada su experiencia.

Respecto de los puzzles y acertijos, son divertidos e interesantes, ponen a prueba nuestro ingenio sin llegar a ser imposibles ni frustrantes y se van complicando conforme nos vamos habituando de forma orgánica. hay diversos tipos de puzzles a lo largo del juego que implican cosas como pulsar palancas en un orden, mover bloques, guiar hadas por un circuito, tocar canciones ♥♥♥ campanas... Todos ellos te proporcionan una buena inyección de autoestima, cuando logras averiguar la solución por tu cuenta, aunque su dificultad está lejos de ser imposible. También hay acertijos verbales que te obligarán a haber mirado tal o cual libro, o simplemente a tener el ingenio necesario para resolver la adivinanza. ¡Sí, a veces habrá que pensar! Delicioso. También hay armas especiales muy poderosas que tienen puzzles insertos, resolver un puzzle significa dar un aumento de poder permanente al arma, e incluso diversos efectos mágicos. Hay que echarle ingenio para desbloquear todo el potencial de las armas de nuestro arsenal.

En cuanto a lo que viene siendo el reparto de galletas, tenemos encuentros no aleatorios (y no siempre forzosos) que nos irán apareciendo en el mapa en forma de grupos de enemigos bien estáticos, bien en movimiento. Una vez entablemos contacto ♥♥♥ los monigotes, el mapa se convierte en una rejilla de 6x4 en la que colocar a nuestros personajes y enfrentar a los rivales. la posición es fundamental, dado que cada personaje tiene unas casillas sobre las que puede incidir, los enemigos se irán meneando y cambiándonos de sitio. Cada turno tenemos X acciones para hacer -que repartimos entre los miembros del grupo- y el enemigo igual, así que hay que ser tácticos. Los personajes del grupo tienen clases que los hacen desempeñar un papel muy distinto en combate, y dentro de cada clase, hay muchas ramificaciones por las que guiar a cada uno de modo que por ejemplo, dos pícaros no van a ser iguales ni cumplir la misma función. ¡El sigilo también es fundamental! antes de atacar a un grupo, es importante emboscarlos sin que nos vean, para tener el primer turno, porque si no, el turno será de ellos, y un turno es la diferencia entre ganar o sufrir una amarga derrota. La única pega quizá al combate es que a mi gusto hay poca variedad entre las formaciones enemigas que nos salen al paso, por lo demás es profundo a la par que dinámico. Los turnos pasan rápido y no se hace pesado en absoluto.

Por último, hablemos de la historia. Es una historia típica y tópica que sirve para enmarcar la aventura y que sin embargo tiene giros interesantes y sorpresas por el camino, amén de una narrativa exquisita, en la que un bardo va contando como si de un cuento se tratase nuestro periplo cada vez que cargamos partida. A demás de la historia principal, hay un buen puñado de misiones secundarias. El juego opta por la calidad de las mismas antes que la cantidad, así que olvidémonos de vernos abrumados por miles de objetivos demandando nuestra atención, en su lugar tendremos unas pocas misiones ♥♥♥ una historia propia más o menos interesante según la cuestión, que nos llevarán por nuevos caminos e incluso a nuevas mazmorras. Esta narrativa se ve reforzada por los cantarines npcs que van dando vida al mundo y por una banda sonora de primer nivel, ♥♥♥ canciones folclóricas que sin duda, podrían ser cantadas por un bardo.

En definitiva: The Bard's Tale IV: Director's Cut es el mejor exponente moderno de su género, una aventura divertida e impresionante y un imprescindible en la biblioteca de cualquiera que quiera disfrutar de una experiencia rolera de primer orden. De los infames bugs no puedo hablar, porque no he experimentado ninguno, ♥♥♥ lo que para mi este juego es sobresaliente. 9/10
 
Eldritch Nadia
0
